questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office for pelvic pain and recurrent pregnancy loss. She has had six months of chronic mild pelvic pain and three spontaneous miscarriages in the last two years. She has no chronic medical conditions. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals mild discomfort with palpation over the uterus. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a 4.2 cm solid, well-defined intramural mass in the fundus of the uterus. There are no features concerning malignancy. Which of the following, if present, would be the greatest risk factor for this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Diet high in fruits and vegetables

questions.solution:
This patient who presents with pelvic pain and recurrent pregnancy loss has evidence of a uterine leiomyoma on ultrasound. Risk factors for uterine leiomyomas include family history of leiomyomas, early menarche, premenopausal status, increasing interval since last birth, hypertension, and obesity.

Uterine leiomyomas, or fibroids, are benign tumors that grow in or around the uterus. They arise from the smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts of the myometrium. Patient presentation is largely dependent on the size, location, and number of leiomyomas present. Leiomyomas may be intramural (i.e., within the muscle layer), subserosal (i.e., underneath the outer lining of the uterus), or submucosal (i.e., underneath the endometrium). Subserosal and submucosal tumors may grow in a “pedunculated” fashion, where the mass is attached to the uterus by a thin stalk.

Most leiomyomas are small and asymptomatic. When symptoms are present they may include heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding, with or without anemia. Other symptoms such as pelvic pressure and pain, urinary frequency, and constipation can result from uterine enlargement. Leiomyomas can also cause reproductive problems, including infertility and miscarriage. The physical examination may be normal, or an enlarged or irregular uterus may be palpated. Occasionally, a prolapsed submucosal leiomyoma is visible at the cervical os.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of uterine leiomyomas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Multiparity:
Incorrect: Having one or more pregnancies extending beyond 20 weeks of gestation decreases the risk of leiomyomas.  
❌ Low body mass index:
Incorrect: Most studies have shown that obesity and increased body mass index (BMI) are associated with an increased risk of uterine leiomyoma. Patients with a low BMI would not be at increased risk of leiomyomas.  
❌ Late menarche:
Incorrect: Early, not late, menarche is associated with increased risk of uterine leiomyoma.  
❌ Diet high in fruits and vegetables:
Incorrect: A diet low in fruits and vegetables has been associated with the development of uterine leiomyomas.

questions.text: A 24-year-old non-binary person with female reproductive anatomy presents for a routine wellness exam. They have regular menstrual cycles, use oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), and are currently sexually active with 1 male partner. Their history includes Chlamydial cervicitis 3 years ago, 6 total lifetime sex partners, and they received all recommended childhood vaccinations. Other than OCPs, they take no medications. Socially, they smoke e-cigarettes regularly, occasionally consume marijuana, and do not consume alcohol. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. On exam, the patient has normal external female genitalia, a normal appearing cervix and vagina, and normal physiologic discharge. A sample taken for cervical cytology returns with low-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL). Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Cytology in one and two years
Calculating the risk of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3

questions.solution:
This patient is 24 years old and is found to have low-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) on cervical cytology. Cervical cancer is rare in young people and cervical dysplasia, especially low-grade dysplasia, frequently resolves. For these reasons, repeat cytology in one and two years is recommended for people aged 21 to 24 with low-grade dysplasia (LSIL) on cervical cytology.       

The evaluation and management of abnormal cervical cancer screening results is different for people 21 to 24 years of age compared to those who are ≥ 25 years of age.        

Younger patients are initially screened with cytology only, which identifies dysplasia; further evaluation with colposcopy and cervical biopsies is only indicated in this population if the cytology shows high-grade dysplasia. A colposcopy exam magnifies the cervix for careful inspection, and biopsies can assess how deeply dysplastic cells actually invade into the cervical tissue. Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) can only be diagnosed with a biopsy.       

On the other hand, in patients ≥ 25, the first step after an abnormal cytology or HPV test is to calculate the immediate risk of CIN3+. Colposcopy is indicated if that risk is 4% to 24%, colposcopy or treatment is appropriate when the risk is 25% to 59%, and treatment is preferred when the risk is at least 60%.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cytology in one and two years:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Routine screening:
Incorrect: Based on the U.S. screening guidelines, the recommended routine screening for individuals 21 to 30 years of age is cervical cytology every three years. Although this patient’s risk of cancer is low, LSIL warrants closer surveillance with repeat screening in one and two years. 
❌ Colposcopy:
Incorrect: In young people ≤ 24 years of age, colposcopy is only performed on patients with high-grade changes on cervical cytology due to high rates of regression in this population. Colposcopy is indicated in patients ≥ 25 years of age with LSIL and a positive human papillomavirus (HPV) screening test. 
❌ Calculating the risk of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3:
Incorrect: Calculating a patient’s risk of CIN3+ is used for patients who are at least 25 years of age and have an abnormal screening result. It is not required in those ≤ 24, like the patient in the vignette. 
❌ Testing for human papillomavirus (HPV):
Incorrect: Testing for HPV is not indicated in younger patients due to high incidence rates along with high rates of regression. It may be acceptable in patients with atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASCUS) because if negative, they can resume routine screening, but if positive, they are managed like this patient with LSIL who requires repeat cytology in one and two years.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G0 woman presents to the gynecology office with heavy bleeding that has been occurring intermittently for the past 9 months. The bleeding is not cyclical and most recently occurred 2 weeks ago. That episode lasted 8 days but has ranged from 2 to 20 days, with the longest interval without bleeding being 3 weeks. The bleeding can be heavy at times, requiring a pad change every 1-2 hours. The patient reports irregular periods since menarche at age 9, typically occurring every 4-6 months. As a teenager, the patient was on birth control to help regulate cycles but stopped at age 20. There has been no follow-up with a doctor since then. Medical history is significant for obesity. An endometrial biopsy reveals crowding of the endometrial glands within the stroma and nuclear atypia. A hysteroscopy with directed biopsies shows no evidence of endometrial carcinoma. The patient desires future fertility. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has had persistent abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) and irregular menstruation for many years, consistent with chronic anovulation. The endometrial biopsy is suggestive of endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN), a precursor to endometrial cancer. Because the patient desires future fertility, progestin therapy is the most appropriate next step.

Management of EIN depends on reproductive goals. For those who are postmenopausal or do not desire fertility, hysterectomy with or without bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is the best management option. This is because endometrial carcinoma is found in up to 50% of cases at the time of surgery. In patients who wish to preserve fertility and have no evidence of carcinoma on endometrial sampling, progestin therapy is appropriate after counseling on the risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma. Progestins counteract the effects of unopposed estrogen on the endometrium and can induce regression of EIN. Options include oral progestins, the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (IUD), or both.

Endometrium sampling should be repeated within 3 to 6 months. If minimal or no response is seen, sampling should be repeated after another 3 to 6 months. If there is no response after 9 to 12 months, a hysterectomy may be indicated. If there is a resolution of EIN, progestin therapy is generally continued for 2 years due to the risk of recurrence. If symptoms return after discontinuing treatment, endometrial biopsy should be repeated.

Option Analysis

✅ Progestin therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hysterectomy:
Incorrect: Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) in individuals who have completed childbearing or do not wish to preserve fertility. This option is not appropriate given the patient’s desire for future fertility.
❌ Monitoring:
Incorrect: Monitoring is appropriate management for benign findings on endometrial biopsy. However, this patient’s biopsy is consistent with endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia, (EIN) which is abnormal and requires further management to prevent progression to carcinoma.
❌ Copper intrauterine device (IUD):
Incorrect: The copper IUD is an excellent form of birth control. However, it does not contain progesterone and will not help cause regression of endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN).
❌ Chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Chemotherapy can be part of the treatment for endometrial cancer, depending on pathological grade and surgical staging. This patient’s endometrial biopsy is consistent with endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN), not endometrial cancer; therefore, chemotherapy is not appropriate.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with ovarian cancer presents to the oncology clinic to discuss starting chemotherapy. She will be receiving cisplatin. The patient is concerned about the possible adverse effects of this regimen since her friend, who underwent the same treatment regimen, developed renal failure and is now receiving dialysis. In addition to adequate hydration, the patient inquires if there are medications to help reduce the side effects. Which of the following best describes the medication's mechanism of action that can mitigate cisplatin-associated nephrotoxicity?

choices.text: Detoxification and scavenging of free radical species

questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity is a significant concern in patients receiving platinum-based chemotherapy regimens, particularly cisplatin. It is thought to result from the formation of free radical species. Amifostine, along with sufficient hydration, can be used to minimize this side effect.  

Patients receiving platinum-based chemotherapy should be counseled to maintain adequate hydration. This goal may be accomplished by using saline to prevent the build-up of chemotherapy in the kidneys. Diuresis with mannitol (an osmotic diuretic) may also be used as it increases urination and, therefore, eliminates platinum-containing agents from the kidneys.    

In addition to adequate hydration and diuresis, amifostine may be used to prevent nephrotoxicity. The proposed mechanism of action is via detoxification and scavenging of free radical species.    

Other significant side effects of platinum-containing medications include ototoxicity, nausea and vomiting, neurotoxicity, bone marrow suppression, and allergic reactions. Cisplatin causes the most severe nephrotoxic and neurotoxic effects. Carboplatin is more likely to cause bone marrow suppression. Oxaliplatin comparatively has the mildest side effect profile.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cross-linking of DNA strands:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how platinum-containing agents prevent cellular DNA replication and repair. In contrast, amifostine is used to avoid cisplatin-associated nephrotoxicity and works via a different mechanism of action.  
❌ Binding of acrolein:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how mesna prevents hemorrhagic cystitis in patients receiving cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide. Mesna concentrates in the bladder and binds to acrolein, a urotoxic breakdown product of cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide.   
❌ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase:
Incorrect: Amifostine is used to prevent cisplatin-associated nephrotoxicity and works by scavenging free radicals produced by cisplatin. Amifostine does not affect the function of thymidylate synthase.  
✅ Detoxification and scavenging of free radical species:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reversal of ATP depletion:
Incorrect: This is the proposed mechanism by which nicotinamide (vitamin B3) is thought to decrease the risk of developing non-melanoma skin cancers (NMSC). UV radiation reduces the capacity for DNA repair by depleting ATP stores. Nicotinamide can restart this process as it is a precursor of NAD+, a cofactor required for ATP production. Moreover, it may be recommended for prophylactic use in patients with an extensive history of NMSC.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a primary care clinic for a routine health check-up. She has a history of diabetes type 2 and HIV, for which she is not on treatment due to not having had insurance coverage. In a review of systems, she mentions having irregular menstrual cycles. Her family history is unremarkable. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and consumes alcohol socially. She became sexually active at age 20 and is currently sexually active with one partner and uses barrier protection.  She hasn’t had a pap smear in over 8 years, and inquires about screening options. Which of the following elements of her history places her in the highest-risk category for cervical cancer requiring increased frequency of surveillance?

choices.text: Age of onset of sexual activity

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a routine clinic visit and is due for cervical cancer screening. Her HIV status places her at an elevated risk of developing cervical cancer, necessitating increased frequency of surveillance.  

Cervical cancer is associated with various risk factors. The primary risk factor is persistent infection with high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV), which is transmitted sexually. Other factors that can increase the risk of developing this disease include a history of smoking, multiple sexual partners, early onset sexual activity, and a history of other sexually transmitted infections (STIs), such as chlamydia or HIV. In addition, patients who are immunocompromised (e.g., HIV infection, immunosuppressants) have a significantly increased risk, since the body's ability to fight off HPV infections is impaired.    

Women in the high-risk category, particularly those with HIV or other immunosuppressive conditions, require a tailored approach to cervical cancer screening. For high-risk patients, screening should occur more frequently and may utilize different screening techniques. For women with HIV, HPV testing alone is not recommended, and either a pap smear with cytology alone or co testing with cytology and HPV testing is recommended. Routine colposcopy may be performed with the initial cervical cytology examination. By adjusting screening protocols based on individual risk factors, healthcare providers can ensure early detection and prompt treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ HIV infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Irregular menstrual cycles:
Incorrect: Irregular menstrual cycles may be a symptom of various health issues; however, it is not directly correlated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.  
❌ Age of onset of sexual activity:
Incorrect: Early age of onset of sexual activity increases a patient's risk of cervical cancer. However, this patient became sexually active at the age of 20 years old, which is not considered early.
❌ Social alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Moderate alcohol consumption is not strongly linked to cervical cancer and would not warrant frequent screening. 
❌ Uncontrolled diabetes:
Incorrect: Uncontrolled diabetes can lead to a variety of health complications, it is not a direct risk factor for cervical cancer and would not lead to a change in the usual surveillance recommendations.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the office with dull pelvic pain for the past three days. She reports frequent bloating prior to her menses that subsides within a few days of the onset of menstruation. The bloating has persisted throughout her last 2 cycles. She does not have early satiety, urinary symptoms, hirsutism, vaginal bleeding or discharge. Medical history is significant for ovarian cystectomy of a benign cystic teratoma. Family history is non-contributory. She has not been sexually active for the past 6 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals right lower abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. Pelvic examination reveals a 10 cm firm, mobile mass on the right. Pelvic ultrasound shows an 11 cm solid right ovarian mass with internal vascularity and no ascites. Laboratory findings include an elevated LDH level of 850 U/L. AFP, hCG, CA-125, Inhibin A, Inhibin B, estradiol and testosterone levels are within normal limits. Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be seen, given the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of pelvic pain and bloating in a 22-year-old woman, a solid ovarian mass with internal vascularity on ultrasound, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, points strongly towards a diagnosis of dysgerminoma. The "fried egg" appearance is a hallmark feature of dysgerminomas. It refers to the tumor cells being large, with clear cytoplasm and central, rounded nuclei. The clear cytoplasm surrounding the nucleus resembles the white of a fried egg, while the nucleus itself resembles the yolk. Lymphocytic infiltration, also characteristic of dysgerminomas, further aids in confirming the diagnosis.

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. It typically presents in adolescent and young women as a unilateral solid ovarian mass but may be bilateral in 10% to 20% of cases. It is occasionally associated with gonadal dysgenesis. While LDH is elevated, other tumor markers are not typically elevated. Therefore, the presence of normal levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), CA-125, inhibin A, inhibin B, estradiol, and testosterone, further supports a diagnosis of dysgerminoma in this patient. In addition, the patient lacks symptoms suggestive of hormonal imbalances, such as virilization and irregular bleeding, that are often seen with other types of tumors.

When a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of an ovarian neoplasm, the main objective is to determine if it is benign and can be managed expectantly or malignant, requiring more immediate intervention. Ultrasound findings that are consistent with malignancy include a complex mass with septations, solid components, increased doppler flow, and the presence of ascites. Tumor markers may help make the diagnosis and distinguish among the various types of ovarian cancer, but are not definitive. In the end, a definitive diagnosis can only be made with pathologic examination.
 

Dysgerminoma characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes. Clear cytoplasm and a centrally placed nucleus, with a “fried egg” appearance. H&E Stain.
Image Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Psammoma bodies:
Incorrect: Psammoma bodies are concentric calcifications found in certain tumors such as papillary serous carcinoma of the ovary (epithelial ovarian cancer). They are not characteristic of dysgerminomas. This 22-year-old patient with a normal CA-125 tumor marker is not likely to have epithelial ovarian cancer.  
❌ Schiller-Duval bodies:
Incorrect: Schiller-Duval bodies, which are papillary structures with central blood vessels, are characteristic of yolk sac tumors, which are a type of germ cell tumor. Although possible in this young age group, given the normal AFP level, this diagnosis is less likely. This 22-year-old patient is more likely to have dysgerminoma and would have pathology showing a fried egg appearance.  
❌ Call-Exner bodies:
Incorrect: Call-Exner bodies are small fluid-filled follicle-like structures found in granulosa cell tumors, a type of sex cord-stromal tumor. They are not associated with dysgerminomas. The absence of elevated inhibin and estrogen levels, common in granulosa cell tumors, as well as the absence of hyperestrogenism symptoms, such as irregular bleeding, makes this diagnosis less likely.  
✅ Fried-egg appearance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reinke crystals:
Incorrect: Reinke crystals are rod-shaped crystalline inclusions present in Leydig cells of Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, a type of sex cord-stromal tumor. They are not associated with dysgerminomas. The absence of elevated inhibin, AFP, estradiol, and testosterone, and clinical evidence of virilization makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with abdominal bloating, early satiety, and an 8 pound weight loss over the past 4 months. She also has alternating diarrhea and constipation, urinary frequency, and diffuse abdominal pain for the past 2 months. She does not have vaginal bleeding or dysuria. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes controlled by diet and hypertension controlled with chlorthalidone. She is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol. Her family history is significant for a mother who died of breast cancer at 69. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness and a fluid wave on percussion. Pelvic examination reveals a fixed 12 cm irregularly shaped right sided mass, an irregular 5 cm mobile left sided mass, cul-de-sac nodularity and a cystocele. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a 12 cm mass on the right, a 6 cm mass on the left, and the presence of ascites. Both masses are complex with solid and cystic components. CA-125 level is elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Biopsy of the ovarian masses and neoadjuvant chemotherapy
Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omentectomy
Exploratory laparotomy, surgical staging, and maximal cytoreductive surgery
Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2
MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient who presents with abdominal bloating, abdominal pain, early satiety, weight loss, urinary frequency, alternating bowel habits, and physical exam findings of bilateral irregular pelvic masses, cul-de-sac nodularity, ascites, and a cystocele, likely has a diagnosis of advanced epithelial ovarian cancer. An elevated CA-125 level further supports this diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in the management of advanced ovarian cancer is to perform an exploratory laparotomy, surgical staging, and maximal cytoreductive surgery.

The first ovarian cancer surgical objective is to determine accurate FIGO staging. Accurate staging helps to determine prognosis and guides treatment decisions. The second objective is to perform maximal cytoreduction or debulking, removing as much cancer tissue as possible. Patients with minimal residual disease after surgery, preferably only microscopic, or at least with gross disease 2 cm or less in diameter, will have higher survival rates. To achieve these surgical goals, various procedures are performed, including peritoneal washings, careful examination of the abdomen and pelvis to identify all sites of cancer spread, biopsy of suspicious areas and adhesions, infracolic omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, selective lymphadenectomy of pelvic and paraaortic nodes, and excision of all possible tumor masses.

Following surgery, this patient with advanced ovarian cancer should be treated with adjuvant chemotherapy, likely a combination of paclitaxel and carboplatin. Maximal cytoreductive surgery followed by chemotherapy will give her the best chance for prolonged survival. Survival rates in ovarian cancer are determined by disease stage at diagnosis, and in patients with advanced stage disease, by the amount of residual tumor remaining after cytoreductive surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Biopsy of the ovarian masses and neoadjuvant chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Biopsy and neoadjuvant chemotherapy would not be considered standard first-line management of this patient with likely advanced ovarian cancer. Biopsy without first attempting staging and cytoreduction would usually be reserved for patients who are medically unfit for surgery. Based on the medical history, this patient is fit for surgery. Cytoreductive surgery followed by chemotherapy will give her the best chance of long-term survival.  
❌ Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omentectomy:
Incorrect: Performing only a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and omentectomy would be an incomplete surgical procedure for this patient with likely advanced epithelial ovarian cancer. This surgery omits other important surgical components needed for complete FIGO staging. Optimal management also requires maximal cytoreduction.  
✅ Exploratory laparotomy, surgical staging, and maximal cytoreductive surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2:
Incorrect: Although BRCA mutations can increase ovarian cancer risk, BRCA testing is not the most appropriate next step in management. Patients with suspected advanced ovarian cancer first need surgical evaluation followed by treatment with chemotherapy. Genetic counseling and testing may be performed later, especially with a family history of breast cancer, and would be important information for other cancer-free family members considering testing.  
❌ MRI of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient has a history and physical examination suggestive of advanced ovarian cancer. She already had an ultrasound, which is the recommended first-line imaging modality, with findings consistent with a malignant ovarian mass. MRI may be useful in cases where the ultrasound findings are indeterminate. Surgical evaluation should be performed on this postmenopausal woman with suspicious ovarian masses.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care office due to heavy menstrual bleeding. Her periods have been getting progressively heavier and more prolonged over the past nine months, sometimes lasting up to ten days and requiring her to use several menstrual pads per hour. She also has a feeling of fullness in her pelvic region. She is sexually active with one male partner. Her last period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals an enlarged uterus with an irregular contour by palpation. Pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is concerning for a uterine leiomyoma, given the patient’s history of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic fullness; and the enlarged, irregular uterus palpated on examination. The first step in the evaluation of suspected uterine leiomyoma is a pelvic ultrasound.

Uterine leiomyomas can vary widely in size and location in or on the uterus. Due to this variability, accurately diagnosing them may require a combination of imaging techniques. Pelvic ultrasound should always be the first step in the diagnostic workup. It may not detect all tumors; therefore, if the pelvic ultrasound is unrevealing or inconclusive, additional visualization methods may include sonohysterogram or hysteroscopy. A sonohysterogram is performed by injecting a small amount of saline into the uterine cavity during a transvaginal ultrasound, opening the endometrial cavity to allow inspection of the contours of the endometrium. The procedure is especially useful in cases of pedunculated submucosal leiomyomas. A hysteroscopy (see graphic below) consists of inserting a camera into the endometrial cavity, along with saline to inspect the inner lining of the uterus. This method can be used to visually diagnose and treat submucosal leiomyomas. Magnetic resonance imaging is typically performed ahead of surgical planning in complex cases, or when there is continued diagnostic uncertainty. Laboratory testing can be performed to determine if there is pregnancy or anemia. Endometrial biopsy should be performed when there is concern for malignancy.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hysteroscopy:
Incorrect: A hysteroscopy involves inserting a camera into the endometrial cavity and infusing saline to inspect the inner lining of the uterus. It can be used to visually diagnose and treat submucosal leiomyomas. However, this patient has not yet had a pelvic ultrasound, which is the initial step in the diagnostic workup of a suspected uterine leiomyoma.  
❌ Sonohysterogram:
Incorrect: A sonohysterogram is performed by injecting a small amount of saline into the uterine cavity during a transvaginal ultrasound to open up the endometrial cavity and inspect the contours of the endometrium. It is useful in cases of a suspected pedunculated leiomyoma when a pelvic ultrasound does not detect the lesion. However, a standard pelvic ultrasound is the first step in the workup.  
❌ Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect: Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can provide a more detailed evaluation of the uterus in cases where the pelvic ultrasound is unrevealing, non-diagnostic, or for surgical planning in complex cases. However, a pelvic ultrasound should be the first step before considering MRI.  
❌ Pelvic computed tomography:
Incorrect: A pelvic computed tomography (CT) scan can provide additional information about pelvic organs when a pelvic ultrasound is inconclusive or unrevealing and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is contraindicated. However, it is not the preferred method for pelvic imaging due to its limited detail of pelvic soft tissues and the risks associated with radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 12 hours after experiencing penetrative sexual assault by a partner. The patient reports anxiety and fear, with mild abdominal and pelvic discomfort but no significant bleeding or head trauma, and consents to a forensic examination. There is no prior medical or surgical history, no medications, and no known allergies. There is no history of substance use or prior trauma. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On initial assessment, there are no external injuries, but the patient appears significantly distressed. Which of the following individuals should be consulted first?
questions.solution:
This patient is a survivor of penetrative sexual assault. A sexual assault nurse examiner or sexual assault medical forensic examiner has specialized training in trauma-informed care, forensic evidence collection, and providing emotional support. Consulting these examiners first ensures adherence to evidence-handling protocols, minimizes contamination, addresses medical needs, and reduces the risk of re-traumatization.   

Evaluation within 7 days of assault includes a trauma-informed history, physical examination, testing for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and pregnancy, and forensic evidence collection if the patient consents. Local guidelines determine the time frame for evidence collection, often within 72 hours but in some areas up to 7 days. Prior to the exam, patients should avoid bathing, changing clothes, defecating, urinating, douching, oral rinsing, cleaning fingernails, smoking, eating, or drinking. Jurisdictions typically provide sexual assault collection kits with checklists, specimen containers, documentation forms, and instructions.   

When the assault occurred more than 7 days earlier, evaluation should also include screening for post-traumatic stress disorder, anxiety, depression, substance use, and chronic pain.    

In all cases, arrange mental health support, ensure a safety plan, and explain mandatory reporting laws before any disclosure to law enforcement, in accordance with local regulations and patient preferences.   

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced a sexual assault, you can call RAINN National Sexual Assault Telephone Hotline at 800.656.HOPE (4673) or visit https://rainn.org/ to be connected with a trained staff member from a sexual assault service provider in your area.        P.P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced intimate partner violence, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope for Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources   

Option Analysis

❌ Obstetrician/gynecologist (OB/GYN):
Incorrect: While OB/GYNs are skilled in reproductive health, most are not specifically trained in forensic evidence collection for sexual assault. Initiating consultation with an OB/GYN before a trained forensic examiner could delay standardized evidence collection and increase the risk of compromised legal admissibility. 
❌ Mental health professional:
Incorrect: Mental health professionals provide essential psychological support, but they are not trained to perform forensic examinations or address the immediate medical needs in sexual assault cases. Their involvement is typically coordinated after initial medical-forensic care is completed. 
❌ Social worker:
Incorrect: Social workers play a critical role in resource coordination, crisis intervention, and safety planning, but they generally do not perform forensic examinations or acute medical assessments. Their role is supportive rather than clinical in the immediate forensic context. 
❌ Law enforcement:
Incorrect: Law enforcement agencies are responsible for investigations and legal procedures but are not trained to perform medical or forensic examinations. Engaging law enforcement before a trained forensic examiner can risk compromising evidence integrity. 
✅ Sexual assault nurse examiner:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of two days of persistent nausea and vomiting. She reports fatigue and intermittent, crampy lower abdominal pain. She has been taking ibuprofen daily for the pain. She has no fever, diarrhea, or history of recent travel, but she does have a history of kidney stones. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 110/70 mmHg, heart rate 96 beats per minute, and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft with mild diffuse abdominal tenderness and without rebounding, guarding, or costovertebral angle tenderness. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) discontinuation and discharge

questions.solution:
This young woman of reproductive age who is sexually active with a male partner presents with acute vomiting and crampy lower abdominal pain, which could stem from various conditions. The history of kidney stones and NSAID use raises suspicion for urological or medication-related etiologies; however, pregnancy should always be ruled out first in biologically female patients of reproductive-age presenting with these symptoms. A urine β-hCG test is the fastest, non-invasive, and cost-effective way to confirm or exclude pregnancy, which could explain the symptoms and direct further workup for conditions such as hyperemesis gravidarum, ectopic pregnancy, or spontaneous abortion.

Formulating and prioritizing a differential diagnosis for an adult with acute vomiting involves considering gastrointestinal, gynecological (if biologically female), and extra-abdominal causes based on clinical presentation. Gastrointestinal etiologies include infectious gastroenteritis, appendicitis, bowel obstruction, and pancreatitis, while gynecological causes include pregnancy ectopic pregnancy, and ovarian torsion. Extra abdominal causes include increased intracranial pressure and metabolic disturbances such as diabetic ketoacidosis. Diagnostic testing (e.g., serum electrolytes, liver function tests, urinalysis, β-hCG, and imaging (e.g., CT scan, ultrasound)) should be based on the most likely causes.

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominopelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominopelvic ultrasound can be used to evaluate potential gynecological or urological causes of vomiting and abdominal pain such as ectopic pregnancy or hydronephrosis; however, a urine β-hCG test should first be performed in this patient who is of reproductive age.  
✅ Urine β-hCG test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis :
Incorrect: CT imaging is not appropriate as the initial step due to the risks of radiation exposure if the patient is pregnant. CT of the abdomen/pelvis is less specific for gynecological causes of vomiting and abdominal pain than a pelvic ultrasound, and it should only be performed after first ruling out pregnancy.
❌ Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) discontinuation and discharge:
Incorrect: Discontinuing NSAIDs would be appropriate if gastritis was the cause of this patient's vomiting and abdominal pain. However, pregnancy or another gynecologic condition is more likely in this case, and pregnancy should always be ruled out in a biologically female patient of reproductive age prior to considering discharge.
❌ Abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: Abdominal X-rays would have limited diagnostic utility in this scenario and would not effectively identify pregnancy or other gynecologic causes of her symptoms. Additionally, pregnancy should be ruled out in a biologically female patient of reproductive age to avoid unnecessary radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit and raises a concern for recent voice changes. The patient has noticed a deepening and hoarseness of his voice over the past eight weeks and is worried “something is wrong with my voice box.” His parent reports the patient has been sleeping 10-12 hours per day and had a “head-cold” two months ago. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. He does not smoke, use illicit drugs, or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a tall, thin male in no acute distress with comedonal acne noted on the face. The patient’s posterior oropharynx is without evidence of edema, exudates, or erythema. There is no tenderness to palpation of the trachea. When asked to speak, the patient's voice intermittently enters higher frequency registers. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Enlargement of the larynx and longer, thicker vocal folds
Recent infection with a parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of voice changes consistent with normal development during puberty. During the physical examination, the patient has a characteristic “voice crack,” which refers to a person's voice suddenly and unintentionally entering a higher register.  

The hormonal changes males experience during puberty influence the anatomy of the larynx, ultimately resulting in enlargement of the larynx and the development of longer, thicker vocal folds. As these structures enlarge and change, the fundamental frequency of the vocal cords decreases, resulting in a deeper pitch to the voice.    

Option Analysis

✅ Enlargement of the larynx and longer, thicker vocal folds:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent infection with a parainfluenza virus :
Incorrect: Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, may cause transient changes in phonation, including deepening of the voice. This patient’s presentation is consistent with normal anatomic changes associated with puberty. 
❌ Subglottic stenosis :
Incorrect: Subglottic stenosis refers to a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords and above the trachea. This condition is often congenital or acquired after prolonged mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Vocal fold paralysis:
Incorrect: Unilateral vocal fold paralysis results in a hoarse or breathy voice. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis causes dyspnea and potentially a complete airway obstruction. This patient’s presentation is consistent with normal anatomic changes associated with puberty. 
❌ Respiratory papillomatosis :
Incorrect: Respiratory papillomatosis is a rare disorder characterized by the development of small, wart-like growths in the respiratory tract.  Involvement of the larynx can result in voice change, most commonly a hoarse, gravelly voice. It is more likely this patient’s symptoms are related to normal anatomic changes associated with puberty.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate anaphylaxis following a bee sting. The patient received intramuscular epinephrine in the field without resolution of symptoms. Upon initial evaluation, the patient is in respiratory distress using accessory muscles. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 41/min, blood pressure is 82/50 mmHg, and O2. is 82% on room air. Additional intramuscular epinephrine is administered without resolution of symptoms. The decision is made to intubate for airway protection; however, the emergency physician cannot visualize the vocal cords with video laryngoscopy or direct laryngoscopy due to airway edema. Repeat vital signs are as follows: temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 41/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 60/32 mmHg, and O2. is 60%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in respiratory distress due to treatment-resistant anaphylactic shock. The emergency physician cannot establish a definitive airway due to airway edema. Given this patient's impending respiratory arrest, the most appropriate next step in management is performing a cricothyrotomy for definitive airway management.  

Cricothyrotomy and tracheostomy are two surgical procedures to establish an opening for ventilation and respiratory support in the trachea. Cricothyrotomy is the emergent airway procedure in the “can’t intubate, can’t ventilate” scenario. The procedure is performed by making a vertical incision over the cricothyroid membrane into the trachea, followed by the insertion of an endotracheal tube. It is preferred to tracheostomy because it is easier to perform, is associated with less bleeding, and can be performed more quickly.  

In contrast, a tracheostomy is a planned procedure performed for patients with a prolonged course of mechanical ventilation to decrease work of breathing and improve patient comfort when compared to endotracheal intubation. Additional indications include vocal cord paralysis, previous neck surgery or throat trauma, and chronic upper airway obstruction. This procedure is performed by making a horizontal incision midway between the cricoid cartilage and the sternal notch, with subsequent placement of a tracheostomy tube.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cricothyrotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tracheostomy :
Incorrect: A tracheostomy refers to a surgical opening in the trachea. Tracheostomy is not the preferred approach in most patients who require the establishment of an emergency airway. 
❌ Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation:
Incorrect: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a salvage therapy that circulates the patient’s blood through an artificial oxygenating device in the setting of respiratory failure. This patient is critically ill and will decompensate further unless an immediate airway is established.   
❌ Fiberoptic intubation:
Incorrect: Fiberoptic intubation is often performed in patients with significant airway edema; however, this patient is critically ill and will decompensate further unless an immediate airway is established.   
❌ Needle cricothyrotomy:
Incorrect: Needle cricothyrotomy is an option to establish an emergency surgical airway, but it is not the procedure of choice in most adult patients. It is used more commonly in pediatric patients. However, even in the pediatric setting, it is still not the first-line choice as ventilation is difficult through a small caliber cannula, and it requires an unobstructed airway for passive expiration. As such, this patient is not a candidate.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician to evaluate difficulty feeding and recurrent stridor for several weeks. The patient has been persistently regurgitating feeds and intermittently becomes stridorous while playing. The parents became more concerned when the patient started “turning blue” occasionally. His birth history was uncomplicated, but he has dropped off his growth chart trajectory since his last well child check. Vital signs are within normal limits. With attempted feeding in the clinic, the patient vomits and becomes stridorous. The patient is subsequently sent to the emergency department, where a computed tomography (CT) of the chest is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Stenosis of the left subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for evaluation of recurrent dysphagia, vomiting, and respiratory distress. These findings are concerning for an anatomic anomaly. CT of the chest subsequently demonstrates a vascular ring of the aorta – specifically, a double aortic arch.   

Vascular anomalies of the aorta include a double arch of the aorta, a retro-esophageal right subclavian artery, and a right arch of the aorta.  

A double aortic arch occurs when two different take-offs from the aorta occur and then reform posterior to the trachea and esophagus. Ultimately this forms a ring around the esophagus and trachea, which can compress these structures and potentially result in difficulty breathing and swallowing.    

A retro-esophageal right subclavian artery refers to a right subclavian artery that arises in the left chest and subsequently courses posterior to the esophagus and trachea. This condition is most commonly asymptomatic but can result in recurrent dysphagia.  

Lastly, a right arch of the aorta represents an aorta that courses to the right of the trachea instead of its usual course to the left of the trachea. This condition represents a mirror image of normal aortic anatomy and is associated with certain genetic disorders. However, it is not pathologic in nature.    

Option Analysis

✅ Double arch of the aorta:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right arch of the aorta :
Incorrect: A right arch of the aorta represents a mirror image of normal aortic anatomy. While this anatomic anomaly is associated with certain genetic disorders, it is not pathologic and would not account for this patient’s symptoms. 
❌ Stenosis of the left subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Subclavian steal syndrome is a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery. Physiologically, this condition reverses blood flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery, which can lead to vertebrobasilar ischemia. In addition, patients can manifest with exercise-induced ischemia of the affected limb. 
❌ Pulmonary infundibular stenosis :
Incorrect: Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot and is the most important marker of prognosis. While this condition could partially explain this patient’s respiratory distress, it does not explain the history of dysphagia. 
❌ Coarctation of the aorta:
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta refers to a discrete narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. In severe cases, the condition can present with findings of heart failure in infancy.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents for follow-up evaluation regarding surgical treatment options for recently diagnosed non-small cell lung cancer. After several months of fatigue and dyspnea on exertion, the patient underwent CT imaging of the chest and was found to have a 6 cm mass occupying the medial segment of the right middle lobe. Biopsy of the lesion was consistent with large-cell carcinoma. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option based on this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer – specifically large cell carcinoma, an aggressive malignancy amenable to surgical resection. Of the surgical resection options listed, the most appropriate course of action is a right middle lobe resection, referred to as a lobectomy.   

Lung resections are often required in clinical practice to control aggressive malignancies or infectious processes. The right lung consists of ten bronchopulmonary segments, organized into three lobes. The left lung is also composed of ten segments, but it is organized into two lobes. In general, most tumors are removed through a lobectomy, wherein the entire lobe is removed to ensure an adequate margin of tumor removal.  

Other resection methods include a segmentectomy, wherein a single segment of the lung is removed. However, this procedure is reserved for those with associated pulmonary or cardiovascular comorbidities who would be unable to tolerate the removal of a full lobe. Other procedures include pneumonectomy, in which the entire lung is removed, and wedge resection, which refers to the non-anatomic removal of a portion of the lung (often reserved for biopsies).    

Option Analysis

✅ Right middle lobectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right pneumonectomy:
Incorrect: Right pneumonectomy refers to removing the entirety of the right lung. Based on the anatomic location of this patient’s malignancy, removing the entire lung would be inappropriate. 
❌ Right medial middle lobe segmentectomy:
Incorrect: A segmentectomy (anatomic sublobar resection) removes one or more segments by dividing their contributing arterial, venous, and bronchial elements. This procedure is often reserved for treating patients with tumors who cannot tolerate larger pulmonary resection due to underlying pulmonary disease or cardiovascular comorbidities. 
❌ Wedge resection:
Incorrect: Wedge resection is the non-anatomic removal of a portion of the lung, meaning the contributing vessels and minor airways are not individually dissected and ligated. This procedure is more commonly performed for biopsy of a lesion rather than curative resection.  
❌ Right sleeve resection:
Incorrect: A sleeve resection is an alternative to a pneumonectomy that involves removing a lobe containing a target lesion with a portion of the lobar bronchus to an uninvolved lobe.

questions.text: A three-month-old baby is being seen for follow-up. She has been a noisy breather since birth. She has difficulty feeding and has episodes of dyspnea and stridor. Stridor and dyspnea improve with neck extension and worsen with neck flexion. Supine and prone positioning have no effect on symptoms. Her weight is 12<sup>th</sup> percentile and length is 40<sup>th</sup> percentile. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 35/min, blood pressure is 80/55, and oxygen saturation is 99%. On physical examination, she has monophasic wheezing but no increased work of breathing. She has no cyanosis or murmur and has 2+ femoral pulses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of noisy breathing since birth, difficulty feeding, occasional dyspnea and stridor, and monophonic wheezing on examination is consistent with a vascular ring/sling. In patients with a vascular ring/sling, symptoms improve with neck extension and worsen with neck flexion.

When assessing a patient with a lower airway obstruction, it is key to identify onset of symptoms. Onset is typically categorized into congenital, abrupt onset, subacute onset, and gradual onset. Diseases with gradual onset can be further differentiated based on the triggers for the symptoms. Triggers can range from environmental, such as cold temperature and exercise in the setting of asthma, to feeding in cases of GERD. Position changes are another trigger of symptoms in cases of tracheobronchomalacia and vascular ring/slings. Patients with tracheobronchomalacia are more affected by supine vs. prone position (symptoms worsen with supine position), whereas patients with vascular ring/sling are more affected by neck flexion vs. extension (symptoms worsen with neck flexion).

Oftentimes, the history and physical examination will allow for high clinical suspicion in cases of lower airway obstruction, but ultimately, additional testing is necessary for formal diagnosis. Bronchoscopy can be used to diagnose tracheobronchomalacia. CTA, MRA, or barium swallow study as part of initial work up can diagnose vascular ring/sling. Pulmonary function tests can be used to diagnose asthma.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vascular ring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tracheobronchomalacia:
Incorrect: Patients with tracheobronchomalacia present similarly to patients with vascular rings but their symptoms are affected by prone vs. supine positioning. This patient’s symptoms are affected by neck flexion and extension and not by prone vs. supine positioning; therefore, she is more likely to have a vascular ring.  
❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Patients with asthma are typically older and present with cough and/or wheeze. This patient’s age, difficulty feeding, and stridor are not consistent with asthma. When there is concern for asthma in older patients, spirometry can confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ GERD:
Incorrect: Patients with GERD typically have a cough and diffuse wheezing that worsen after feeds. Although this patient does have difficulty feeding, her history of occasional stridor and monophonic wheezing is more consistent with a compression of a larger airway, such as is seen with a vascular ring/sling. GERD is often a clinical diagnosis, but pH probe monitoring is the gold standard in diagnosis.  
❌ RSV:
Incorrect: Patients with RSV have a subacute onset of symptoms and usually have other infectious symptoms such as fever and rhinorrhea. This patient’s symptoms are more chronic and are affected by positioning making a vascular ring the more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician’s office for a well-child examination. She has a history of meconium ileus at birth and has had chronic constipation in addition to recurrent sinus and pulmonary infections. Her mother has a niece and grandfather who both had chronic pulmonary conditions diagnosed when they were young children. The patient is at the 28<sup>th</sup> percentile for height and the 6<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.4°C (99 F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 104/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97%. On physical examination, she appears thin and in no acute distress. Nasal polyps are visualized. Tympanic membranes are within normal limits bilaterally. Pulmonary exam reveals diffuse rhonchi without increased work of breathing. Heart rate is regular with no murmur appreciated. Which of the following additional findings would be expected given the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of meconium ileus, chronic constipation, and recurrent sinus and pulmonary infections. On physical examination nasal polyps and rhonchi are present. These findings along with a family history of pulmonary disease make cystic fibrosis the most likely diagnosis. Cystic fibrosis (CF) can also cause pancreatic insufficiency which can lead to bulky, foul-smelling stools (steatorrhea).

Cystic fibrosis is caused by a mutation in the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene resulting in a defect in chloride channels affecting organs with secretory functions like the lungs and pancreas.  Due to the defect in chloride channels, abnormally viscous secretions that are thick and sticky are produced. This primarily impairs airway clearance and increases the risk of respiratory infection. It often results in pancreatic insufficiency leading to steatorrhea characterized by frequent, bulky, foul-smelling stools that may be oily, and failure to thrive or poor weight gain due to malabsorption of fat and protein. Patients may also experience acute or recurrent pancreatitis and focal biliary cirrhosis. Newborns with CF may present with meconium ileus or prolonged jaundice. On physical examination, patients with CF can have evidence of nasal polyps, digital clubbing, rales or rhonchi on lung exam, and hepatomegaly. Patients may also have rectal prolapse. Chest x-ray may show bronchiectasis.

Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) also present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections. These patients are also prone to recurrent otitis media with or without hearing loss and may have situs inversus. PCD is associated with abnormal ciliary movement. Newborns with primary ciliary dyskinesia often have mild respiratory distress and may require supplemental oxygen for a few hours to days after birth. On physical examination, patients can have nasal polyps, digital clubbing, and middle ear effusions. Chest x-ray can show bronchiectasis.

Both CF and PCD are associated with infertility. Infertility in males with CF is due to the congenital absence of the vas deferens. Women with CF can develop secondary amenorrhea and hyperviscous reproductive tract mucus which impairs fertility. Patients with PCD can develop infertility due to the immotility of sperm and abnormal ciliary motion within the fallopian tubes and endometrium.

Option Analysis

✅ Bulky, foul-smelling stools:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Situs inversus:
Incorrect: Situs inversus (ie organs in the chest and abdomen are inverse) can be present in some cases of primary ciliary dyskinesia. However, this patient likely has cystic fibrosis which is not associated with a laterality defect.
❌ Absent thymus:
Incorrect: Thymus is absent in immunodeficiencies such as Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) or DiGeorge syndrome. Although this patient suffers from recurrent infections; the history of meconium ileus, constipation, and family history of pulmonary disease makes cystic fibrosis the most likely underlying diagnosis. CF is not associated with absence of the thymus.
❌ Glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Glomerulonephritis is a late manifestation of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency which can present similarly to cystic fibrosis. This patient’s history of meconium ileus, constipation, family history of chronic pulmonary disease, and recurrent respiratory infections is more consistent with cystic fibrosis.
❌ Sweat chloride < 30 mmol/L:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis causes an elevation of sweat chloride, specifically a sweat chloride > 60 mmol/L.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for evaluation of recurrent sinusitis and pulmonary infections. She has been frequently sick and missing school, and the parents are concerned. She has a history of chronic constipation, and her parents report she has large stools that float in the toilet. She is at the 14<sup>th</sup> percentile for height and the 4<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8 F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99%. On physical examination, the patient appears thin but is otherwise interactive and playful. Pulmonary exam reveals mild diffuse rhonchi without increased work of breathing. Heart rate is regular with no murmur appreciated. The patient is referred for a sweat test which reveals a sweat chloride level of 68 mmol/L. Which of the following should be ordered next to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of recurrent sinusitis, pulmonary infections, constipation, and steatorrhea. Initial work-up reveals a sweat chloride level of 68 mmol/L. This abnormal test should be confirmed with a repeat sweat chloride test. Two positive sweat chloride results confirm a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF).

When cystic fibrosis is suspected, the first step is to obtain a sweat chloride test. A sweat chloride level <30 mmol/L is negative, which should prompt consideration of alternative diagnoses. A sweat chloride level of 30-59 mmol/L is intermediate and should be followed up with repeat sweat chloride testing and genetic testing. Two mutations on genetic testing are indicative of CF. A sweat chloride level ≥ 60 mmol/L is positive and two positive results are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) presents similarly to cystic fibrosis. If patients with suspected PCD can perform a nasal Nitrous oxide (NO) test, it can be the initial step in screening for PCD. NO levels are very low or absent in patients with PCD. Very low or absent NO levels suggest PCD and should be confirmed with nasociliary brushing or biopsy and electron microscopy/video microscopy to evaluate ciliary function and structure. In the setting of PCD, electron microscopy will reveal ultrastructural ciliary defects and video microscopy will show abnormal ciliary waveforms. Genetic testing can also be performed to evaluate for mutations in PCD-associated genes.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Repeat sweat chloride test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chest computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: This patient’s history, physical examination, and initial sweat chloride test are consistent with cystic fibrosis. A CT is not necessary to confirm the diagnosis. A repeat sweat chloride test should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Biopsy of nasal mucosa:
Incorrect: Biopsy of nasal mucosa for electron microscopy is used to diagnose primary ciliary dyskinesia. This patient has evidence of gastrointestinal malabsorption in addition to recurrent respiratory infections and an elevated initial sweat chloride level, making cystic fibrosis more likely, therefore, a repeat sweat chloride test should be performed.
❌ Nasal nitric oxide (NO) level:
Incorrect: Obtaining nasal nitric oxide levels can be used to initially screen for PCD in patients suspected of PCD, capable of performing the test. This patient has findings consistent with cystic fibrosis which should be confirmed with a repeat sweat chloride test.
❌ Genetic testing:
Incorrect: Genetic testing is used to confirm cystic fibrosis in the setting of an intermediate level sweat chloride result (30-59 mmol/L). This patient has an abnormal sweat chloride level over 60 mmol/L and therefore should have a repeat sweat chloride test to confirm the diagnosis.
